conclusion: To determine the proportionality constant k, analyze the forces acting on the oil droplets and their motion.
The image shows two metal plates with a separation of d, a small hole in the upper plate, and two oil droplets A and B.
Droplet A falls with a uniform velocity v_A through a distance h_1 in time t.
The forces acting on A are gravitational force F_g = m_0 g and air resistance f_A = k m_0^{1/3} v_A.
Since A moves with constant velocity, the net force is zero: m_0 g = k m_0^{1/3} v_A.
Solving for v_A gives v_A = m_0^{2/3} g / k.
Droplet B initially falls with the same velocity v_A as A.
When the voltage U is applied, B begins to move upwards with a uniform velocity v_B through a distance h_2 in time t.
The forces acting on B are gravitational force F_g = m_0 g, air resistance f_B = k m_0^{1/3} v_B, and electric force F_e = q E, where E = U/d.
Since B moves with constant velocity upwards, the net force is zero: m_0 g + k m_0^{1/3} v_B = q U/d.
From the motion of B, v_B = h_2/t.
Substitute v_B into the force balance equation: m_0 g + k m_0^{1/3} h_2/t = q U/d.
Solving for q gives q = d/U (m_0 g + k m_0^{1/3} h_2/t).
We have two expressions for v_A and v_B: v_A = m_0^{2/3} g / k and v_B = h_2/t.
Since v_A = v_B, m_0^{2/3} g / k = h_2/t.
Solving for k gives k = m_0^{2/3} g t / h_2.
The proportionality constant k is k = m_0^{2/3} g t / h_2.
